repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - First and Second Development
            Policy Loan in Support of the Plan Maroc Vert

abstracts.cdata!:
The First and Second Development Policy
            Loan in Support of the Plan Maroc Vert received a moderately
            satisfactory outcome rating with significant risk to
            development outcome. The Bank received a satisfactory rating
            for its performance while the Borrower received a moderately
            satisfactory performance rating. No restructurings took
            place during the life of this project. Country developments
            led to three changes in the agreed prior actions for the
            second operation. These changes were: (a) the substitution
            of an agreement on the management model at Berkane for the
            previously proposed action on three wholesale market pilot
            projects. The concept remained the same but essentially the
            target was reduced from three to one. (b) The addition of
            the executive decision on market liberalization for red meat
            to the proposed action on concession to the private sector
            of modernized municipal slaughterhouses. (c) The
            substitution of the transmission of the draft laws creating
            the Regional Agriculture and Rural Development Offices
            (ORDARs) for the previously proposed action raising
            irrigation tariffs. There were several lessons learned from
            this project including the following: (1) A development
            policy loan (DPL) works best when it stems from a home-grown
            reform program with strong ownership within government. (2)
            A further strong value of Bank support under a DPL is to
            help create a platform for agencies that otherwise may have
            divergent agendas. (3) The linking of a DPL to a sectoral
            medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) aligns incentives
            for both the finance ministry and the line ministry, and
            provides investment resources to accompany and help
            implement reforms that otherwise might not take place or
            might not yield their intended returns. (4) In the case of
            Morocco, submission of draft legislation to the Government
            General Secretary (SGG) may be inadequate assurance that a
            reform will be promptly executed. (5) Evaluation of a DPO is
            constrained by the short time scale, particularly for a two
            loan series, where the final evaluation occurs only twelve
            months after the second set of prior actions. (6) There is a
            need  and an opportunity  to accompany some reforms with
            project-style guidance and investment.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - First Development Policy Loan in
            support of the Plan Maroc Vert Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
Executive Directors approved a First
            Development Policy Loan (DPL) in support of the Plan Maroc
            Vert Project for the Kingdom of Morocco in the amount of
            Euro 150 million (US$ 205 million equivalent) on the payment
            conditions set out in the President's Memorandum
            (R2011-0039). Executive Directors welcomed the operation,
            noting it will improve reforms in the agricultural sector
            while advancing environmental and social sustainability and
            enhancing the efficiency in domestic food markets. While
            agreeing that the DPL series is underpinned by significant
            analytical work, and builds on lessons and experience
            learned from previous operations, Directors further
            suggested careful monitoring of mitigation measures.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - First Development Policy Loan in
            support of the Plan Maroc Vert Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the First Development
            Policy Loan in support of the Plan Maroc Vert (PMV) Program
            are to: 1) improve the efficiency of domestic markets; 2)
            improve the socio-economic impacts of investments directed
            to small farmers; 3) improve agricultural services; and 4)
            improve the use and the management of irrigation water and
            the planning of irrigation infrastructures. This program
            document a first Development Policy Loan (DPL) in support of
            the Plan Maroc Vert to the Kingdom of Morocco. The operation
            is the first of a programmatic series of two single tranche
            DPLs. The program supports an ambitious government
            initiative in the agriculture sector and builds on extensive
            dialogue between the World Bank and the Government of
            Morocco (GoM) and is underpinned by a large body of
            analytical work and sector operations. The program has
            benefited from a broad range of analytical work recently
            completed by the World Bank and others. The program also
            builds on the outcomes and experience from past and ongoing
            bank operations in water and irrigation, integrated rural
            development, human development, and public sector
            administration reform. Additional value added of the World
            Bank includes bringing global best practice lessons to the
            implementation of the PMV as well as encouraging
            inter-ministerial dialogue. With the involvement of the
            private sector Morocco designed and is implementing specific
            sector strategies to increase investment and employment in
            sectors of the economy with high growth potential. Thus,
            investment in these sectors has increased, strengthening the
            fundamentals of the economy.
